content.webTitle: Tommy Makinson and solid defence guide St Helens to Wakefield win

fields.headline: Tommy Makinson and solid defence guide St Helens to Wakefield win
fields.bodyText: The knives have been out for St Helens, the Super League leaders, over the last fortnight by their own coach’s admission and, while this was not an inch-perfect return to form, it will certainly calm any unnecessary nerves surrounding the recent form of Justin Holbrook’s side. Given how they have sauntered through the majority of this season, it was perhaps inevitable that defeats by Catalans in the Challenge Cup semi-finals and Huddersfield last weekend were met with questions over whether the Saints were able to last the pace this year. In that context this was at least something of a silencing from the Saints on a ground where victories – certainly not ones by 20 points – do not come easily. “I think we’re back to our normal selves,” Holbrook said. “The boys showed that tonight and it was important to do so.” The platform was laid for victory here in the first half. Following a defensive performance showing few of the frailties which have plagued the Saints in their past two games, a seven-minute spell yielded 16 unanswered points. While Wakefield twice pulled that back to within a score after half-time, it always felt as though the Saints had Trinity at arm’s length. Visits to Wakefield have become increasingly reliable acid tests for sides in recent years, though this defeat for Trinity now all but ends their hopes of a play-off push this season. That should not necessarily be considered a failure given their considerably lower spend than most sides. “We’ve lost a lot of close games this year and it’s frustrating,” their coach, Chris Chester, lamented. “That spell in the first half saw us come up with six errors in nine sets.” The game was scoreless for 25 minutes before two tries for Tommy Makinson – the winger who continues to look like a serious contender for England honours this autumn – plus Jonny Lomax’s first of the night made it 16-0 at the break. Trinity, much to their credit, hit back when Kyle Wood and Pauli Pauli crossed. But in the 10-minute period when Trinity were without Craig Huby – in the sin-bin – Theo Fages re-established a two-score lead. That was again cut when Bill Tupou scythed through but the visitors finished the stronger, tries for Luke Douglas and Regan Grace confirming restoration of their 10-point lead at the top of the table. Wakefield Jowitt; Jones-Bishop, Lyne, Tupou, Johnstone; Miller, Hampshire; Fifita, Randell, England, Ashurst, Batchelor, Horo. Interchange Wood, Pauli, Arona, Huby. Tries Wood, Pauli, Tupou Goals Hampshire 2 St Helens Barba; Makinson, Costello, Percival, Grace; Lomax, Richardson; Amor, Roby, Douglas, Taia, Knowles, McCarthy-Scarsbrook. Interchange Fages, Wilkin, Lees, Ashworth. Tries Makinson 2, Lomax, Fages, Douglas, Grace Goals Richardson 6 Referee Liam Moore.
